threats.title: Spoofing credentials
threats.description: An attacker steals a patient's credentials by phishing (for example fake Login page) and uses their account to manipulate applications.
threats.mitigation: Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) and educate users on phishing risks

threats.title: Denial of Fake Document Submission
threats.description: A patient denies that he submitted fake documents.
threats.mitigation: To mitigate repudiation, implement audit logs.

threats.title: Repudiation of Refund Actions
threats.description: The system or an attacker later denies or disputes having processed a particular transaction, making audits difficult.
threats.mitigation: Log all steps in the refund process with unique transaction IDs and timestamps.

threats.title: Misconfigured endpoints
threats.description: Sensitive patient or financial data could be leaked via the web app (misconfigured endpoints).
threats.mitigation: Implement strong access

threats.title: Denial of Service
threats.description: Attackers flood the web application or exploit resource‐intensive operations to make it unavailable.
threats.mitigation: Use rate‐limiting and automated monitoring to detect and block DDoS.

threats.title: Repudiation of Refund Actions
threats.description: A normal user finds a way to change their privileges (e.g. from ‘patient’ to ‘admin’ or from ‘employee’ to ‘super user’) by manipulating the frontend.
threats.mitigation: Make a role check in the backend and not in the frontend.

threats.title: User Impersonation Attacks
threats.description: An attacker could impersonate a legitimate user if authentication mechanisms are weak. This allows unauthorized individuals to submit or view someone else’s claims.
threats.mitigation:
Require strong passwords, enforce multi-factor authentication, and use secure session management (HTTP-only, secure cookies).
Enforce TLS/SSL to prevent session hijacking or credential sniffing over the network.

threats.title: Denial of Claim Submission or Modification
threats.description: A user or administrator could deny having submitted or edited a refund claim if the web application does not effectively link actions to specific user identities or store traceable records.
threats.mitigation:
Log each claim submission or modification with user ID, IP address, timestamp, and session details.
Disallow shared accounts; each user must have their own credentials.

threats.title: Admin Credential Theft
threats.description: An attacker acquires admin‐level credentials (phishing or bribe), potentially changing configurations, viewing logs, or manipulating claim data.
threats.mitigation: Enforce MFA and strict password policies for all admin accounts, implement Real‐time alerts for admin logins or critical actions.

threats.title: Admin Repudiation
threats.description: An Admin disclaims having performed certain high‐privilege changes or data manipulations in the system.
threats.mitigation: Securely log all administrative actions, implement “four‐eyes” approval processes for critical admin changes.

text.text:
Employees of

Employees of
the Health
Insurance Company

threats.title: Unauthorized Employee Account Access
threats.description: An attacker could steal the login data of an employee (phishing) or bribe an employee. And then he can take this login and pretend to be an employee.
threats.mitigation: Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) and educate employees on phishing risks

threats.title: Employee Denies Approving Fraudulent Refunds
threats.description: An employee processes and authorises fraudulent claims or alters patient records, but later denies any involvement. Without logging and verification mechanisms, there is no evidence linking the action to the employee.
threats.mitigation: Implement Audit Logs, Role-Based Access Control.

threats.title: Impersonation of Doctor
threats.description: An attacker pretends to be a registered Doctor, issuing false medical statements that could inflate claims or manipulate patient data.
threats.mitigation: Strong authentication with provider identity verification.

threats.title: Doctor Repudiates Approved Claims
threats.description: A Doctor might deny having approved or validated a given claim/receipt, undermining the system’s trust.
threats.mitigation: To mitigate repudiation, implement audit logs.

threats.title: Database Record Manipulation
threats.description: Attackers or malicious insiders could alter stored refund records, patient data, or billing information in the database.
threats.mitigation:
Use cryptographic checksums or digital signatures for critical records so that any unauthorized modifications can be detected.
Limit who can modify or delete records to a minimal set of trusted roles. Log every change with timestamps and user identifiers.

threats.title: Untraceable Database Transactions
threats.description: A user, admin, or application component might execute changes on the data server (e.g., updating patient information or refund status) without leaving sufficient evidence to link the action back to a specific identity. They could then deny responsibility if the changes have harmful consequences.
threats.mitigation:
Each account that connects to the database (or data service) should be uniquely identifiable; do not share generic credentials across multiple users.
Record transaction details (e.g., user ID, timestamp, data affected) in a tamper-evident audit log.

threats.title: Sensitive Data Exposure
threats.description: The data server may store sensitive patient records, medical billing, or payment details. If not properly secured, attackers or unauthorized insiders could access or exfiltrate confidential data.
threats.mitigation:
Encrypt sensitive data at rest (e.g., using transparent database encryption) and in transit (TLS/SSL connections).
Enforce the principle of least privilege for database users and services—only grant minimal required permissions.

threats.title: Resource Exhaustion on the Data Server
threats.description: An attacker might flood the data server with excessive or malformed queries (e.g., a large number of refund data requests) to saturate CPU, memory, or I/O resources. This can slow down or crash the server, preventing legitimate transactions from being processed.
threats.mitigation:
Configure the database to limit the number of concurrent connections and queries from a single source or user.
Continuously monitor query performance and detect anomalies (e.g., sudden spikes in query volume). Implement alerts and automated actions to handle suspicious surges.

threats.title: Denial of Service
threats.description: Attackers send malformed documents/requests to overload the verification component, preventing claims from being processed.
threats.mitigation: Validate document formats and enforce strict size limits.

threats.title: Misconfigured endpoints
threats.description: Attackers discover an unprotected endpoint in the verification API that grants higher‐level system privileges.
threats.mitigation: Require authentication/authorization checks on every API call.

threats.title: Impersonation of the Verification Service
threats.description: An attacker could impersonate the Document Verification Application by exploiting weak service authentication or insecure service endpoints.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt all traffic using TLS, ensuring the authenticity of the application’s endpoints via properly signed certificates.

threats.title: Altering Verification Results
threats.description: Attackers or malicious insiders could modify the verification outcome (e.g., marking an invalid document as valid) or change metadata (timestamps, user IDs) within the Document Verification Application.
threats.mitigation:
Limit who can modify verification results; log all changes for audit.
Digitally sign or hash verification records to detect unauthorized changes.

threats.title: Denying Document Approval Actions
threats.description: A verifier or administrator might deny having approved (or rejected) a document if the system does not securely link each action to a unique identity. This makes auditing and incident investigations difficult.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce multi-factor authentication for all users interacting with the verification interface.
Record user IDs, timestamps, document IDs, and relevant context for each verification event in tamper-proof logs.

threats.title: Leaking Sensitive Document Data
threats.description: The Document Verification Application may handle personal or confidential information (e.g., medical details, billing data). If access controls or encryption measures are insufficient, unauthorized parties could view or intercept these sensitive documents.
threats.mitigation: Use robust encryption (e.g., AES at rest, TLS in transit) for all document data.

threats.title: Information Disclosure via Logs
threats.description: Logs contain sensitive personal/medical data (like names, receipts, diagnoses) that could be accessed by unauthorized parties.
threats.mitigation: Scrub or mask PII (personally identifiable info) before writing to logs.

threats.title: Refund Form Manipulation
threats.description: An attacker or a dishonest user could modify the refund submission form—e.g., by manipulating hidden fields or directly altering POST parameters—to request a higher refund amount or fake receipts. This compromises the integrity of the refund process.
threats.mitigation:
Never rely solely on client-side checks; verify all critical data on the server.  
Implement strict validation rules to prevent injection or unexpected data formats.

threats.title: Transaction Denial by Users
threats.description: A user could submit a refund request, then later deny having done so, claiming that someone else used their account. Without proper authentication and logging, it becomes difficult to prove who initiated the transaction.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce multi-factor authentication for any refund submissions to ensure only authorized users can initiate a transaction. 
Log each request with a timestamp, user ID, IP address, and session details.

threats.title: Log Server Flooding
threats.description: An attacker could overwhelm the Log File Server with excessive log messages (e.g., by generating continuous error events), exhausting server resources or disk space, leading to slowdowns or crashes.
threats.mitigation: Implement controls to cap the number of log events accepted from a single source or IP per time window. Continuously monitor log volume and configure alerts for abnormal surges, enabling timely response to a potential DoS attack.

threats.title: Information Disclosure via Logs
threats.description: Logs contain sensitive personal/medical data (like names, receipts, diagnoses) that could be accessed by unauthorized parties.
threats.mitigation: Scrub or mask PII (personally identifiable info) before writing to logs.

threats.title: Refund Approval Log Manipulation
threats.description: Attackers could modify or delete log entries indicating that a refund was approved or denied. For example, someone might alter the log to show a higher refund amount or remove the record of a refund approval entirely.
threats.mitigation:
Use digital signatures or secure hashing to verify that log files have not been altered.
Grant write permissions only to a dedicated logging service or highly restricted admin accounts, and monitor all changes.

threats.title: Denying Responsibility for Refund Approvals
threats.description: A user or administrator could deny having approved (or denied) a refund if the logs do not reliably associate every refund decision with a unique and authenticated identity. This might lead to disputes or difficulties in regulatory audits.
threats.mitigation:
Ensure all users have unique credentials; use multi-factor authentication to strengthen identity verification.
Record highly accurate timestamps (NTP-synced) and store context data (e.g., IP addresses, session IDs) in the logs.

threats.title: Log Server Flooding
threats.description: An attacker could overwhelm the Log File Server with excessive log messages (e.g., by generating continuous error events), exhausting server resources or disk space, leading to slowdowns or crashes.
threats.mitigation: Implement controls to cap the number of log events accepted from a single source or IP per time window. Continuously monitor log volume and configure alerts for abnormal surges, enabling timely response to a potential DoS attack.

threats.title: Manipulation of documents during transmission
threats.description: An attacker could altering receipts or metadata to commit fraud, potentially via Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) attacks.
threats.mitigation: Implement TLS encryption (HTTPS) for secure transmission, document hashing to verify integrity.

threats.title: Exposure of Patient Data via Insecure Transmission
threats.description: When a patient submits documents or personal health information to the web application, the data may be transmitted without encryption (over HTTP instead of HTTPS)
threats.mitigation: Enforce HTTPS, Encrypt patient data before transmission

threats.title: Excessive recipe submissions
threats.description: An attacker or bot can flood the Web Application with excessive recipe submissions, either by repeatedly submitting requests manually or by automating the process using scripts.
threats.mitigation: Implement rate limiting and throttling, CAPTCHAs on submission forms, web application firewall.
